context: Most of the Korean Presbyterian denominations share the same name in Korean, 대한예수교장로회 (literally means the <a0_0>Presbyterian Church of Korea<a0_0/> or PCK), tracing its roots to the United Presbyterian Assembly before its long history of disputes and schisms. The Presbyterian schism began with the controversy in relation to the Japanese shrine worship enforced during the Japanese colonial period and the establishment of a minor division (Koryu-pa, 고려파, later The Koshin Presbyterian Church in Korea, Koshin 고신) in 1952. And in <a1_0>1953<a1_0/> the second schism happened when the <b5_0>theological orientation of the Chosun Seminary (later Hanshin University) founded in <a3_0><b6_0><b7_0>1947<b7_0/><b6_0/><a3_0/> could not be tolerated<b5_0/> in the PCK and another minor group (The Presbyterian Church in the Republic of Korea, Kijang, 기장) was separated. The last major schism had to do with the issue of <a2_0>whether the PCK should join the WCC<a2_0/>. The controversy divided the PCK into two denominations, The Presbyterian Church of Korea (Tonghap, 통합) and The General Assembly of Presbyterian Church in Korea (Hapdong, 합동) in <b8_0>1959<b8_0/>. All major seminaries associated with each denomination claim heritage from the <b9_0>Pyung Yang Theological Seminary<b9_0/>, therefore, not only Presbyterian University and Theological Seminary and Chongsin University which are related to PCK but also Hanshin University of PROK all celebrated the 100th class in <a4_0>2007<a4_0/>, 100 years from the first graduates of Pyung Yang Theological Seminary.
